title: Swede Score
description: Predicts colposcopically high-grade lesions (HGL) on histology in cervical cancer screening. This standardized colposcopy scoring system evaluates five key characteristics to guide clinical decision-making and treatment planning for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

parameters.name: aceto_uptake
parameters.description: Acetowhite uptake after application of acetic acid during colposcopy

parameters.name: margins_surface
parameters.description: Characteristics of lesion margins and surface pattern
options: Sharp and even, with surface level difference

enum: Sharp and even, with surface level difference

parameters.name: lesion_size
parameters.description: Size of the lesion or number of quadrants involved

ranges.interpretation: Score <5 indicates low risk for high-grade cervical lesion. Consider routine follow-up or targeted biopsy based on clinical suspicion.

ranges.description: Consider biopsy based on clinical suspicion
ranges.interpretation: Score 5-7 indicates intermediate risk. Consider colposcopy-directed biopsy for histopathological confirmation before treatment planning.
Score ≥8 indicates high suspicion for high-grade cervical lesion. Consider excisional treatment (LEEP, cone biopsy) at time of colposcopy ('see and treat' approach).

references: Strander B, Andersson-Ellström A, Milsom I, Rådberg T, Ryd W. Liquid-based cytology versus conventional Papanicolaou smear in an organized screening program : a prospective randomized study. Cancer. 2007 Dec 25;111(6):285-91. doi: 10.1002/cncr.23100.

Bowring J, Strander B, Young M, Evans H, Walker P. The Swede score: evaluation of a scoring system designed to improve the predictive value of colposcopy. J Low Genit Tract Dis. 2010 Oct;14(4):301-5. doi: 10.1097/LGT.0b013e3181d77756.
formula: Swede Score = Aceto uptake points + Margins/surface points + Vessels points + Lesion size points + Iodine staining points (total 0-10 points)
notes: Each parameter scored 0, 1, or 2 points for a total maximum score of 10
Score ≥8 has high specificity (90-100%) for high-grade lesions
Score ≥5 has high sensitivity (92-100%) for detecting high-grade lesions
Useful for 'see and treat' protocols in resource-limited settings
Helps standardize colposcopic evaluation and reduce inter-observer variability
Should be used in conjunction with cytology and HPV testing results
Particularly valuable for training novice colposcopists
Can guide decision between surveillance, biopsy, or immediate treatment
